message: Clickable link:  http://lissn.com/vip
Lissn will be slowly moving from anonymous to social over the next few weeks. Usernames will function as an identity & url, similar to twitter usernames.
Interesting concept. Reminds me of irc... Hope you will find your users! (interface a bit tricky on iPad btw)
Thanks!  We are working on an ipad version :)
Excellent, good to know. We did it the other way around because one of our Guys is a real iOS genius, so by the time we thought Web he already was done with the iPhone app.
Native App, or only WebApp?
Start off as a web app, then native
hah..  wish we had one of those!
Sooo how are you going to prevent omegle esque trolls and asl *disconnect* type usage?
you mean 1v1v1?
omegle is 1 on 1 private, lissn is 3 on 3 public, hopefully that is enough to deter some trolls.  other mechanics can be added
we are adding some user remembering features soon :)
standing up from a conversation was fun!
found myself leaving a conversation by sharing my convore id
from a usability point of view, the "walk away" button needs to move. Every other app has trained me, the user, to hit the "submit" button on the right of a text input.
looking forward to seeing the effect of usernames...
haha yes
hmm interesting. ill give it a try
hmm... maybe it'll take?
Disallowing a '+' symbol in my email address means I won't sign up, btw.
Ah didnt realize '+' wasnt allowed.  I will allow it in signup :)
What's the point of Lissn?? What problem is it trying to solve? What demographic is it trying to reach??
The '+' is still not allowed!

I have been playing with this. Like chatroulette for text. I just wish I could flag some people as cool and interesting. I also wish I could find out what my password is! Recover password link would be very useful.

/vip assumes your visitors will let you store cookies on their computer, otherwise you welcome them with this:

Forbidden (403)

CSRF verification failed. Request aborted.
Help

Reason given for failure:

    No CSRF or session cookie.
    

In general, this can occur when there is a genuine Cross Site Request Forgery, or when Django's CSRF mechanism has not been used correctly. For POST forms, you need to ensure:

    * The view function uses RequestContext for the template, instead of Context.
    * In the template, there is a {% csrf_token %} template tag inside each POST form that targets an internal URL.
    * If you are not using CsrfViewMiddleware, then you must use csrf_protect on any views that use the csrf_token template tag, as well as those that accept the POST data.

You're seeing the help section of this page because you have DEBUG = True in your Django settings file. Change that to False, and only the initial error message will be displayed.

You can customize this page using the CSRF_FAILURE_VIEW setting.
